May be a bug in JDT/UI?
Looks like invalid edits. Please move back if this isn't the case.
I can't reproduce this in I20061108-0800, can you? It would be interesting to debug.

I can reproduce this bug in code that compares two files and edits a target file based on the differences.
Interestingly enough, the problem does not occur if the target file (a web.xml) is  open in a WST editor, but it occurs every time if the target file is not open in the editor.

 org.eclipse.wst.sse.core.internal.text.JobSafeStructuredDocument

I'm attempting to produce a test case to reproduce the bug.

A key difference between editor open scenario and editor closed scenario, is that when there is no editor open the text change is "reverted" when ModelManagerImpl.releaseFromEdit() is called.  This does not happen when there is an editor open.  

The releaseFromEdit() calls revert(IDocument), which sets the document content to its original value.  If the original value of the document is smaller (ie: has fewer characters) then a DocumentEvent is created with a large length, which in turn causes the undo collector to set its fLength member to a negative value in this method:


	public void documentChanged(DocumentEvent event) {
		fLength+= getDelta(event);
	}

The negative length then later causes the assertion failure.

So the key settings for repeatability seem to be:

1. The target file cannot be open in an editor (ResourceTextFileBuffer.revert() must be called)
2. the edits must cause the file to become larger than the original document

I hope that helps.  Here's a stack trace of the code when the UndoCollector.fLength becomes negative:

I can easily reproduce this in M3 with steps from comment #0, but not in I20070601-0010 anymore. Marking as WORKSFORME.

David, what you mean by 'reproducing this bug'? Do you get the same stack trace (please provide your trace)? Or with the steps from comment #0? We don't own a class called ModelManagerImpl. Maybe you want to open a new bug against the web tools project, if you have steps to reproduce your problem?

Benno,

Thanks for looking into this.  I'll open a new bug.  Initially I thought they were related, since the exception comes from TextEdit.internalSetLength however now it's clear to me that they are two different issues.
